149. Beaton, Edith Emily (Mrs. S.)
Name: Mrs. Edith Reaum
Address: Raynton
Birthplace: Ireland

1. Domestic Duties
   - What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1903
   - Where did you set up housekeeping? Raynton
   - How far was it to your nearest store? About 2 miles
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a month
   - What groceries did you usually buy in those earlier years? Sugar, oatmeal, syrup, dried fruits, beans, flour, rice, cream of wheat

2. Flour and Other Grain Products
   - What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? I think at first, "Blue River," later "Sunrise," a Battleford product
   - In what quantities did you buy it? 10 to 15 sacks (100 lbs)
   - What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
   - How much did you use graham flour? 25 lbs
   - Whole wheat flour? Yes
   - Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 25 miles, what year? Maybe 1910
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.75
   - What other grain products did you use? Wheat, cornmeal, barley
   - Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
   - How did you grind it? At first coffee mill, then grain grinder

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? .................................................... Pork, beef, cured.

How did you get fresh meat? ............................................................................. Fishing, hunting, bought from neighbors.

How often did you get fresh meat? .................................................................... Monthly.

How did you preserve meat? ............................................................................ At first we made canned beef, later on we learned to can in sealers.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ................................................ Yes, for about 2 years.

If so what year was it organized? ....................................................................... About 1928.

Did you use game? ............................................................................................ Sometimes.

What kinds? ....................................................................................................... Prairie chicken.

For how long? ..................................................................................................... As long as we could get it.

What part did fish play in the family diet? ............................................................ In early months when game was scarce, selling crayfish.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ............................................................... Fresh, salted, frozen.

Kinds? .............................................................................................................. Whitefish, jackfish, pickerel.

20. Notice any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

A warm semi-modern house, and the advent of quick yeast in bread making has been a big help. Also we have learned to freeze bread, pies, cookies. We used to cut beef into "joints" and files of slabs of steak and spread on boards. We kept them turned then packed them in snow in boxes.

We still freeze some for winter, but our meat for summer will go to the locker plant 20 miles away. It's far, but we feel it's worthwhile.

21. Did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

With a family of six children, we made our own bread always, maybe for 30 years, never relied on prepared foods.

Have made own vinegar, soda, yeast cakes, coffee. One year we dried raspberry leaves to use for tea. This latter was in the nature of an experiment.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

For a number of years, we sent a grocery order to Eaton's, after they opened a branch store in Winnipeg. This was general among the farmers, and was much resented by the business men in town.

May I explain that from 1903 to my marriage in Dec 1905 I stayed with Mr. & Mrs. Pete Paynter probably the earliest settlers in this part of Sask. Mr. Paynter used to say that he knew everyone living between Battleford and Edmonton prior to the coming of the Bay party.

Mrs. Paynter kept a stopping place for travellers.
After a number of years, we opened a grocery store in Minneapolis. This was general among the farmers, and was much resented by the business men in town.

I explain that from 1903 to my marriage in Dec. 1905 I stayed with Pete Paynter, probably the earliest settler in this part of town. Paynter used to say that he knew every one living between Battleford and Edmonton (prior to the coming of the Boys Harvey). He paid a stopping place for Maxwell.
To accommodate tired and hungry people on their way west:
Having no spare bedrooms, Mrs. Paynter made beds in living room carpet. Sometimes Mr. and Mrs. Paynter gave up their bedroom, and themselves slept on the living room carpet. This according to the status of the person or persons concerned.
